articles.headline: A Stranded $2 Trillion Overseas Stash Gets Closer to Coming Home
articles.snippet: Consensus emerges among politicians, including both presidential candidates, that companies’ foreign profits should be brought back to America. But how?
articles.abstract: Consensus emerges among politicians, including both presidential candidates, that companies’ foreign profits should be brought back to America. But how?
articles.lead_paragraph: The next president may have a rare opportunity to close tax loopholes that have let American corporations stash more than $2 trillion in untaxed profits outside the United States.

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Loses Defamation Case Over Rape Story
articles.snippet: A jury found liability on the part of the magazine, its parent company and the author of the article.
articles.abstract: A jury found liability on the part of the magazine, its parent company and the author of the article.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone magazine paid the legal price on Friday for its journalistic failings in a 2014 article about a supposed gang rape at the University of Virginia that it had already retracted in the face of widespread criticism.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario, Hawes Spencer and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Harvard Men’s Soccer Team Is Sidelined for Vulgar ‘Scouting Report’
articles.snippet: Assigning sexually demeaning rankings to incoming members of the women’s soccer team leads the prestigious university to cancel the remainder of the men’s season.
articles.abstract: Assigning sexually demeaning rankings to incoming members of the women’s soccer team leads the prestigious university to cancel the remainder of the men’s season.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — They rated the women on a sexual appeal scale of 1 to 10, including explicit descriptions of their physical traits and musings about the women’s preferred sexual positions.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: ‘I Saw My Father Dying’: A View From Aleppo’s Government-Held Side
articles.snippet: A rare visit to the city’s western side revealed weariness and violence despite President Bashar al-Assad’s claims that residents are safe.
articles.abstract: A rare visit to the city’s western side revealed weariness and violence despite President Bashar al-Assad’s claims that residents are safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — The government-held side of Aleppo looks halfway normal: bustling with restaurants, parks, hotel swimming pools and commuters. President Bashar al-Assad’s main pitch to his people is that they are safer in the territory he controls, a far cry from the bombs and hunger on the rebels’ half of the storied and strategic city.

articles.headline: The Closer: Michelle Obama
articles.snippet: Dismissed early on by critics, the first lady has evolved into a powerful presence on the campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Dismissed early on by critics, the first lady has evolved into a powerful presence on the campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The emails to Michelle Obama began flooding in minutes after she spoke out at an October rally in New Hampshire, her voice shaking, about Donald J. Trump’s treatment of women. Sexual assault victims recounted their trauma, fathers poured out anxieties about unhealthy influences on their sons, and a distraught parent agonized over how to explain rape to a 10-year-old.

articles.headline: The Money Management Gospel of Yale’s Endowment Guru
articles.snippet: The mammoth Yale endowment fund run by David Swensen has been a training ground for investment managers, its alumni now scattered through the nonprofit world.
articles.abstract: The mammoth Yale endowment fund run by David Swensen has been a training ground for investment managers, its alumni now scattered through the nonprofit world.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he has done for decades, once a week David F. Swensen convenes his staff — including his cadre of apprentices — for a morning-long meeting among the Gothic revival flourishes and crenelations of the Yale University campus to debate investment ideas.

articles.headline: How LinkedIn Drove a Wedge Between Microsoft and Salesforce
articles.snippet: Once so close they flirted with a merger, the software giants became archrivals when they realized the value of the data amassed by social networks.
articles.abstract: Once so close they flirted with a merger, the software giants became archrivals when they realized the value of the data amassed by social networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a story of love lost after a fight over social media.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Katie Benner

articles.headline: After High-Profile Shootings, Blacks Seek Prosecutor Seats
articles.snippet: Black lawyers, racial justice groups and liberal donors, led by the hedge fund billionaire George Soros, are combining forces to try to propel more African-American district attorneys into office.
articles.abstract: Black lawyers, racial justice groups and liberal donors, led by the hedge fund billionaire George Soros, are combining forces to try to propel more African-American district attorneys into office.
articles.lead_paragraph: African-American lawyers, racial justice groups and the liberal hedge fund billionaire George Soros are combining forces to try to elect more black prosecutors in response to what they see as an insufficient response by incumbent district attorneys to the killings of black people by the police.

articles.headline: Tense Senate Tussle in New Hampshire Illustrates Murky Finish Line
articles.snippet: A state that once seemed promising for Democrats in their bid to take back the Senate is now seeing a fight for every vote.
articles.abstract: A state that once seemed promising for Democrats in their bid to take back the Senate is now seeing a fight for every vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.H. — Maggie Hassan, the Democratic governor of New Hampshire now running for the Senate, squeezed by an older woman grimly examining some potatoes at a grocery store here last week. “I hope you’ll consider me,” Ms. Hassan said. The woman, still glowering, grumbled, “I might.”

articles.headline: Forget the Cost to the Candidates. This Campaign’s Cost America More.
articles.snippet: Regardless of who wins the presidency, a brutal election battle has left the nation’s image tarnished, in the eyes of its own people and the world.
articles.abstract: Regardless of who wins the presidency, a brutal election battle has left the nation’s image tarnished, in the eyes of its own people and the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world, too, is waiting anxiously for this election to be over:
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Thin Line Splits Donald Trump’s Politics and Businesses
articles.snippet: Would he be into this White House thing for the country’s benefit or his own? His business record reveals a willingness to change course to suit his needs.
articles.abstract: Would he be into this White House thing for the country’s benefit or his own? His business record reveals a willingness to change course to suit his needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump was building casinos in Atlantic City in the 1990s, he spoke of his dream of bringing jobs and development to the hard-luck community. In the end, after all the bankruptcies, layoffs and stiffed contractors, it was Mr. Trump who walked away with tens of millions of dollars in management fees and huge tax deductions that may have helped him avoid paying personal income taxes for nearly two decades.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Appears to Gain Late Momentum on Surge of Latino Voters
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton sought to galvanize Latino voters on Saturday, as early voting signaled their turnout was swelling in states that Donald J. Trump needs to win.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton sought to galvanize Latino voters on Saturday, as early voting signaled their turnout was swelling in states that Donald J. Trump needs to win.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEMBROKE PINES, Fla. — Hispanic voters in key states surged to cast their ballots in the final days of early voting this weekend, a demonstration of political power that lifted Hillary Clinton’s presidential hopes and threatened to block Donald J. Trump’s path to the White House.

articles.headline: If Hillary Clinton Moves to Oval Office, Aides’ Baggage May Be Heavy
articles.snippet: After a campaign season defined by voter weariness with and distrust of Mrs. Clinton, which old hands might follow her to the White House — and should they?
articles.abstract: After a campaign season defined by voter weariness with and distrust of Mrs. Clinton, which old hands might follow her to the White House — and should they?
articles.lead_paragraph: In the final sprint of her campaign, troubled by an F.B.I. inquiry and narrowing polls, Hillary Clinton has held tightly to a handful of advisers who have spent their careers protecting her interests, defending her reputation, and at times sullying it — and their own.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Volkswagen Emissions Scandal Inquiry Widens to Top Levels
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are investigating whether Hans Dieter Pötsch, the carmaker’s former top finance official, failed to warn shareholders about the scandal.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are investigating whether Hans Dieter Pötsch, the carmaker’s former top finance official, failed to warn shareholders about the scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The investigation into emissions fraud at Volkswagen reached the very top of the company on Sunday after the carmaker said that the chairman of the supervisory board, Hans Dieter Pötsch, is suspected by German prosecutors of violating securities laws.

articles.headline: Protesters in Hong Kong Clash With Police Over Lawmakers’ Fate
articles.snippet: Thousands marched before an expected decision from China that may prevent two young people elected to Hong Kong’s legislature from formally taking office.
articles.abstract: Thousands marched before an expected decision from China that may prevent two young people elected to Hong Kong’s legislature from formally taking office.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday, clashing with the police in a protest against an impending decision by China’s Parliament aimed at eradicating a nascent independence movement in the territory.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang, Alan Wong and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Inside Donald Trump’s Last Stand: An Anxious Nominee Seeks Assurance
articles.snippet: Behind the show of confidence orchestrated by Mr. Trump’s staff are the neediness and vulnerability of a once-boastful candidate uncertain of victory.
articles.abstract: Behind the show of confidence orchestrated by Mr. Trump’s staff are the neediness and vulnerability of a once-boastful candidate uncertain of victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is not sleeping much these days.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Ashley Parker, Jeremy W. Peters and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Emails Warrant No New Action Against Hillary Clinton, F.B.I. Director Says
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. informed Congress on Sunday that it had reviewed newly discovered emails and not changed its conclusions about Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private server.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. informed Congress on Sunday that it had reviewed newly discovered emails and not changed its conclusions about Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private server.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, told Congress on Sunday that he had seen no evidence in a recently discovered trove of emails to change his conclusion that Hillary Clinton should face no charges over her handling of classified information.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Beware, iPhone Users: Fake Retail Apps Are Surging Before Holidays
articles.snippet: Hundreds of rogue apps, most of which came from developers in China, have managed to slip through Apple’s review process.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of rogue apps, most of which came from developers in China, have managed to slip through Apple’s review process.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hundreds of fake retail and product apps have popped up in Apple’s App Store in recent weeks — just in time to deceive holiday shoppers.

articles.headline: Wall Street Bonuses Are Expected to Sink for 3rd Straight Year
articles.snippet: Merger and acquisition talks have been active, but the deals’ advisers get paid on completion. This year, antitrust officials thwarted some large mergers.
articles.abstract: Merger and acquisition talks have been active, but the deals’ advisers get paid on completion. This year, antitrust officials thwarted some large mergers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses are expected to decline for the third consecutive year, reflecting a period of busted mergers, limited trading activity and muted hedge fund returns.

articles.headline: Media’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News
articles.snippet: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
articles.abstract: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last year has turned the United States into a country of information addicts who compulsively check the television, the smartphone and the good old-fashioned newspaper with a burning question: What fresh twist could our national election drama and its executive producer, Donald J. Trump, possibly have in store for us now?

articles.headline: How Comcast and NBCUniversal Used Minions to Fuse an Empire
articles.snippet: Supporters of the AT&T-Time Warner deal have pointed to the success of a similar one between Comcast and NBCUniversal, where both sides are thriving.
articles.abstract: Supporters of the AT&T-Time Warner deal have pointed to the success of a similar one between Comcast and NBCUniversal, where both sides are thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Minions, the impish fire hydrant-shaped yellow misfits who exist to serve the world’s most evil villains, would appear to be unlikely mascots for corporate synergy at Comcast, one of the world’s largest media conglomerates.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Scramble to Make Their Final Pleas
articles.snippet: Racing across the electoral map, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump begged voters to see Tuesday’s vote as a choice of almost apocalyptic significance.
articles.abstract: Racing across the electoral map, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump begged voters to see Tuesday’s vote as a choice of almost apocalyptic significance.
articles.lead_paragraph: They campaigned urgently, even frantically, at airfields and arenas, on a college campus in Wisconsin and in a Philadelphia church. Hillary Clinton and Senator Tim Kaine, their prospects brightened by news that the F.B.I. had found no new troublesome emails in a review of Mrs. Clinton’s private server, pleaded with Americans on Sunday to get out and vote as if their very way of life were on the line.

articles.headline: Fear of Donald Trump Helps Democrats Mobilize Hispanics
articles.snippet: Angry at Mr. Trump and energized by Democratic outreach efforts, Latinos are turning out in droves, and could be the difference in the outcome in highly contested states.
articles.abstract: Angry at Mr. Trump and energized by Democratic outreach efforts, Latinos are turning out in droves, and could be the difference in the outcome in highly contested states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump maligned undocumented immigrants as murderers and rapists. Hillary Clinton hired a woman who had lived undocumented for many years as her national director of Latino outreach.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Amy Chozick and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Hong Kong Elected 2 Separatists. China Took Drastic Action.
articles.snippet: By acting against two dissident lawmakers, Beijing is asserting an authority to set policy in the territory, challenging its semiautonomous status.
articles.abstract: By acting against two dissident lawmakers, Beijing is asserting an authority to set policy in the territory, challenging its semiautonomous status.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the nearly two decades since Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, the Communist government in Beijing has tolerated all manner of activity in the city that it generally finds intolerable on the mainland: annual vigils for those killed in the Tiananmen Square massacre, newspapers publishing scurrilous gossip about China’s leaders, huge demonstrations for free elections.

articles.headline: Janet Reno, First Woman to Serve as U.S. Attorney General, Dies at 78
articles.snippet: Ms. Reno’s eight years in the office placed her in the middle of some of the most divisive episodes of the Clinton presidency.
articles.abstract: Ms. Reno’s eight years in the office placed her in the middle of some of the most divisive episodes of the Clinton presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Janet Reno, who rose from a rustic life on the edge of the Everglades to become attorney general of the United States — the first woman to hold the job — and whose eight years in that office placed her in the middle of some of the most divisive episodes of the Clinton presidency, died on Monday at her home in Miami-Dade County, Fla. She was 78.

articles.headline: Warner Bros., Quietly Thriving, Recasts Its Own Story
articles.snippet: The studio, overshadowed by its corporate sibling HBO, is widely viewed as an unsteady operation. But it’s on pace to have one of its most profitable years ever.
articles.abstract: The studio, overshadowed by its corporate sibling HBO, is widely viewed as an unsteady operation. But it’s on pace to have one of its most profitable years ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Behind the beige walls that enclose the Warner Bros. lot here, Kevin Tsujihara has been ruminating on perception versus reality — a classic Hollywood subject onscreen, but one that the studio is now experiencing in real life.
